description.text: Follow me & my projects: twitter.com/MoceriMike

I put on an awesome demo at Mini Maker Faire Chicago Northside, spreading the word about MakerBot and the potential of 3D printing. With me was Chicago based artist Patrick Lichty. 
Our setup comprised of Patrick's and my Thing-o-Matic, two Kinects for scanning, a TV connected to my computer so people could see the modeling process, and an assortment of promo swag.
I scanned attendees and printed them out. They were able to take their models home with them as part of the experience. The process I used and sources are outlined in on our event card (click the second image).

I scaled the models down to .1, scliced using my custom skeinforge profile (ask if you want it), .27mm height, 100mm/s, Jetty's acceleration (3.2z rev336m) with Dan Newman's .altshell skeinforge plugin, and I am using a MK8 nozzle on my MK7 extruder. This allowed for very fast printing with great quality/results.

title: Creality CR-10 Strain relief bracket for heated bed cable

description.text:
This an accessory for the Creality CR-10 3D Printer.

This bracket does not fit on the CR-10 Mini, if you own a Mini have a look to this bracket by Olesmokie https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2742895

The purpose of this bracket is to hold the wires for the heated bed in place to avoid that they wiggle when the bed move which would ultimately lead to breaking the welds or the wires.

The bracket is designed to be installed on the far left screw under the spring as shown on one of the picture. You will typically need to remove the glass bed for that.

The bracket does not touch the heated bed and can be safely printed in PLA. Reverse the cover upside down for printing.

Once the bracket is in place, move the wires a bit toward the bed (to avoid to put too much tension in them) and hold the wire in place with 2 zip ties.

September 22nd, 2017 update

This bracket is now factory installed by Creality3D themselves on their printers. This is with my full consent. Creality3D contacted me to ask if I would agree and very kindly offered me two free printers (CR10S & Ender 4) after I replied positively.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

20%

Here is a box for the official Raspberry 7" Touch Screen dedicated to the Hephestos Prusia i3 from Bq.

I run Octoprint with Touch Ui since a few time, and I wanted to place the screen in useful place.
This case can be hold direct to the frame of the Hephestos with an holder that I design with a 15° angle.
When the screen is in place, I recommend to use an extern spool holder to avoid the frame shaking !

Every file are included in the Sketchup format ! Enjoy !

Voici un boitier pour l'écran tactile officiel Raspberry, spécialement adapté pour l'imprimante Hephestos Prusa i3

J'utilise Octoprint avec Touch Ui depuis quelques temps et je voulais positionner l'écran à un endroit pratique.

Ce boîtier peut être fixé directement sur le cadre de l'Hephestos grace au support que j'ai conçu avec un angle de 15°
Lorsque l'écran est en place, je recommande d'utiliser un porte-bobine externe pour éviter les tremblements du cadre !

Tous les fichiers sont inclus au format Sketchup !

This is a filament guide for the Creality CR-10 Printer.

Basically it will prevent your filament to touch the (greasy) Z-Axis lead screw.

There are 2 versions, one has clip where you can attach the wires from the hotend, the other doesn't.

To install the guide, you just have to clip it in place. If it does not fit, it means that you are the unlucky owner of a printer where the hole for the Z-Axis lead screw was not drilled at the right place (it seems to happen sometimes).

To use the guide, insert the filament in the axis of the extruder hole, as you would normally do, and once it is in place, put it in the hook of the guide.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

15%

description.text:
My kids smashed the little seatbelt knob that prevents the buckle to go to the end of the belt.

Found a couple of other designs but was not satisfied so made my own.

The pin that goes thru the seatbelt is thin enough, not to have to make a bigger hole in the fabric and so should not affect MOT.

I gave the little pin and the surface, facing the seatbelt a bit of superglue, put it on and gave the part with the hole a similar treatment and pressed everything together for 10 seconds with a pair of pliers.

Seems to be working really well.

Printed in blue because i did not have any black PLA.

title: Wall box for battery operated sensor.

description.text:
EDIT: I have now uploaded version 3 of the wall box. The new OpenSCAD file is highly configurable and gives you a few new options with the box. The PCB and battery case that this was originally designed to work with hasn't changed, but with some simple variable changes, different PCBs and/or battery cases can be made to fit.
ENJOY

This is an enclosure for a temperature and humidity sensor that i built for my home automation setup. The sensor is built using an EasyNewbie PCB created by @sundberg84 from the MySensors.org forum.
https://www.openhardware.io/view/4/EasyNewbie-PCB-for-MySensors
Though this enclosure was designed for my Temp and humidity sensor, it can be used for any of a number of different sensor types.

The battery box use for this project is a 2 x AA battery box that I purchased on ebay.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/New-10pcs-2-AA-2A-3V-Battery-Clip-Holder-Box-Case-ON-OFF-Switch-6-Leads-w-Cover-/371080743217?hash=item566622c931

The circuit board mounts on the 4 tabs inside the box and the battery box fits perfectly in the slots provided. The battery slot on one side is open to allow for the wires to drop inside the box.

The wall mounting plate is designed to have the box snap on the top with side clips to hold it in place securely. The box can easily be pulled off the wall with a flat blade screw driver to release the tabs.

EDIT: I have made a couple small modifications to the design of the box. For the new changes download the V2 files. I have left the original files for those that still want them.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The box should be printed outer face side down for best results. Printing with the face side up will require supports due to the box top overhang.

PCB and battery box mounting

Mounting the circuit board and battery box are simple. Wedge the radio module under one of the corner mounting tabs and rest it on the 4 tabs. Use 4 - 2mm x 5mm coarse thread screws in the corners (marked in red in the image) to secure the board in place.

For the battery box, the switch should be placed inside the box. If it is facing out the bottom, the bottom cover will not snap in place. One side of the battery box mounting slots has a relief cut in it marked in yellow on the image. This is the side where the power wires should go to channel inside the box for connecting to the PCB.

Screw placement and battery box orientation More about me

For more information about me and other projects and things by me, take a look at my websirte at https://dan.bemowski.info/

description.text:
Begleri - a fun and simple skill toy. If you don't know what begleri is, go to YouTube. There are many begleri tutorial videos there.

Print two. These are 22mm (slightly larger) round with room for (2) 5/16" nuts to be inserted in the bottom for weight. I use 245 paracord. The pair fully assembled and strung were 28 grams total.

The little extra on the bottom is by design. My first effort didn't have it. This created a sharp crown on the bottom were the nuts enter and were thin - so more fragile. Considering I drop mine often - I beefed up the design a little. I added the old design stl in case someone prefers the minimalist design.

print_settings.Notes:: Prefer ABS or materials that can withstand high temperature and high force/tension. Also elastic materials are preferable. You may consider CNC using higher quality materials.

title: Customizable midway breaker for Ford Ecosport swinging tailgate

description.text:
Many versions of Ford Ecosport, since 2013, have the swinging tailgate that, once open, will open fully. Full opening of the swinging tailgate requires space behind the car. This space sometimes is a challenge for owner, when accessing the boot in tight parking place.

This midway breaker will help stopping the tailgate midway, so that you can keep the tailgate half open, as in the photograph. Owner can still open the tailgate fully by pushing it open further. The angle at which the tailgate movement get high friction midway can be customized by MidAngle parameter (if you use Customizer, or download the OpenSCAD file to modify).

This breaker has 3 parts, if you use Customizer, select appropriate Mode to generate corresponding part. They are assembled to the boot door hinge as shown in the photographs, by 2 pairs of nut & bold. The nuts & bolts are not printed, you will have to get them elsewhere. The nuts have hexagonal perimeter. The size of nut and bolt can be customized (by BoltRadius, BoltCapRadius, NutMaxRadius parameters). Default models are for bolt of radius 2mm, bolt cap radius 3.5mm, nut hexagonal maximal radius of 3.95mm. You can also download the default models.

After printing, embed the nuts in part 3. Try putting part 1, 2 & 3 together and screw the bolt through, to see if they fit and tight, as shown in the photograph of black breaker. If things seem to be OK, then de-assemble them. Open the tailgate fully. Put part 3 behind the hinge, put part 1 & 2 in front of the hinge, then screw the bolts in, to tightly attach the three parts to the hinge. NOTE: part 1 & 2 are not symmetric, try the best fit orientation. See the photographs for reference.

You should print the parts in ABS, 100% infill, to withstand high temperature under the Sun, and strong force at the hinge. Total printing time should be about 4 hours, more or less.

Some more discussions:

In fact part 1 & part 2 can be merged into one part - this will not create any problem while assembling. However, I find breaking into part 1 & part 2 will ease printing setup. Merging part 1 & part 2 will, I believe, require supports while printing, or, to print without supports, require modifying the parts in some way that make the breaker mechanically less robust. But that is just my thought.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Assembled

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Prefer ABS or materials that can withstand high temperature and high force/tension. Also elastic materials are preferable. You may consider CNC using higher quality materials.

comments.author: MPeter

comments.text:
Hi Peter,
there are mostly two reasons. I do not want to have a twisted belt in my hypercube. And I don't like the flanged bearings as ldlers because they have very sharp edges in the inside of the flange. Also the gap for the belt is too small. Conventional pulleys are always more than 1mm wider. My belts are already wearing of on the side surfaces because of that.
But dont get me wrong, I think the original design would work forever and is also very cheap but I do like a cleaner solution in my hypercube.

title: Simply Construction Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The simplest construction set, ever!
Supports flat sticks and straws. 
WARNING: this is a work in progress.

These are the only two parts of Simply: the simplest construction set,ever!! What you need:
-Node part: print as many as you want/need.
-Joint part: print as many as you want/need.
-Flats sticks like the ones used as coffee stirrers, medicals sticks, etc.
or
-Straws Just join the parts to build your structure!!
Enjoy! Note: I provide openScad files. These parts are fully customizable. Just adjust stick's thickness and the wide, and compile. Fast update: now the code supports STRAWS!!!

comments.text: Whoa -- I've been working on the exact same thing! :-o We should compare notes -- I think I'm a little father along than you are, and probably running into same of the same types of problems.  This pictures shows a couple of versions -- the blue one was the original and I tried to print flat. The other one is the most recent version and tried to print on its side. comments.text: Excellent! I've actually learned a lot since I started this in OpenSCAD, so I'll clean up my code a bit to make it easier to tinker with the angle, rotation, and number of connectors. I wanted to be able to make geodesic forms with these with my kids, which is why I "parameterized" things like angle and number of connectors. They were having fun making things like 500-stick meter-long stars lol -- I post a screenshot of one that I thought made a particularly nice pattern.

comments.text: I forgot to mention: I also considering ditching the pre-joined blocks idea in favor of a bunch of little identical stick clips that could be attached (or plugged in) to a central form that had holes at the appropriate angles and directions. I haven't tried anything that requires that kind of tolerance yet with these printers, but I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts on it nonetheless.

author: 2mafpv

description.text: A question came up as to whether or not a 3d printed key could be used in a real lock and this is my first try at answering that question. As demonstrated in the second photo it does actually work the lock (and was used multiple times) though I wouldn't count on it lasting long. It flexes considerably due to the spring tension. Quite a bit hinges on how much torque is needed to be applied to work the lock, but it certainly can work.

Out of an excess of caution I printed this at 0.10mm using 100% fill to maximize strength. And forgot that the design got flipped: this should be printed so that the blade is touching the build plate. Of course, this key only works a matching lock. The process I used to make it was:
  • Scanned key (though a picture would work as well)
  • Imported image as background into modeler
  • Outlined image with a line
  • Measured key dimension and scaled object to match
  • Added thickness
  • Measured and added key channels
    • The print has some significant variation from the model. If the key hadn't work I would've tweaked the model to fit the printer and filament, but (at least for this lock) it was not necessary.

comments.text: Sir, please tell me your home adress =)
comments.author: iSuat

comments.text:
Do you think it's a good idea to post a 3d model of your house key on the internet where everyone can download it?
Or isn't that your real house lock?
comments.author: Leseratte10

comments.text: That is a good question and perhaps I should have been more explicit: that is not my house key. I was torn about what to do because to me this is a very interesting experiment but thingiverse only allows uploading of models. This particular key goes to a door handle lock (as illustrated) and was mounted for testing and the photograph. Personally, I wouldn't use anything less than dead bolts for exterior locks.
comments.author: Leseratte10

comments.text: I would be worried that it would snap off inside the lock and then you would be in trouble...
comments.author: downeym

comments.text: That was my biggest concern as well. I haven't snapped it off in the lock yet, but odds are fairly good that it would snap off ragged instead of a sheer at entry meaning it would be retrievable with pliers. Further, at this thickness it demonstrated considerable resilience -- more than I expected in fact. Sufficiently so that I'm going to experiment with more locks. Still, this is /not/ a replacement for a metal key. If you want a working key, do it in metal. For custom fabbing a CNC mill would be better than using 3d printed plastic.
comments.author: downeym

comments.text: Try using whatever method was used on the Liberator to harden the key.  There's probably a method for adding a little life to the key.

Just measure the length of each bit in YOUR key and then put it in millimeters in the first line of the .scad file like this:
key([7,7,7,7,7,7,7]); The bit order is from right to left while holding the key with flat side facing down.

My attempt to fix my aluminum bed frame that kept distorting and bending when I try to level the bed. I'm still printing the prototype to test but ill update any issues or if it works or not. I'm doing the first prototype in PLA with 20% infill and 0.15mm layer height and a 0.4mm extruder.

UPDATE 20 Mar 17: Othe half of the bed frame added to allow for proper alignment of linear rod bearings. Make sure to print 2 of each edge.

UPDATE 23 MAR 17: Spacer to raise the bed and extend Y print space added to accommodate original Y rods and higher Y belt tensioning assemblies.

comments.author: penkerton

comments.text:
Hey great design idea. On my original aluminium bed support my screw holes are kinda screwed and with one I had to drill a new hole because a screw broke.
I'll test it out when I can print more thermal resistant filaments.
It should work with higher temperatures if you insulate your heated bed and maybe the screws since they also get heated up quite a bit.
I use shortened springs, but I also have long springs to test this with.
comments.author: PokeyDoggo

comments.text: I've been using this bed platform for a few months still the original pla print with no warping or distortion. The platform has recesses to fit the original 8mm springs or I made some nobs with an extrusion that fit in the 8mm recess to keep the screws vertical and stopped using springs all together. Please let me know if you have any problems or possible improvements.
comments.author: PokeyDoggo

comments.text: How did you come out with this project?  Did it solve your problem?  I am having issues with my stock bed support also and am considering your design.
comments.author: jtsorensen1

comments.text: I have noticed a definite improvement in stability at the corners however I did need to add a spacer for the y end stop on my printer as the linear bearings are closer together towards in the middle as opposed to pushed to the corners of the platform.

comments.author: oxarrogantxo

comments.text: email me: [email protected], I'll send you a picture of the missing 2mm.
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: I made version two. Now the spacing is 53mm. So it is better. There's just enough friction to make it work without being concerned about warping the rods. I will post a picture of the missing 2mm. It's under the top hook. The hook does not sit on the rod perfectly. There is a 2mm space between the top of the rod and the underside of the hook. The original design was probably fine. The radius just needed to be increased. Please email me at [email protected] so I can send you the picture. I think over time, the friction will reduce from mounting the object on the rods over and over again. So at some point, it will be loose. That change over time will make using the dial gauge more difficult, as it is very sensitive. Better to have the perfect radius (8mm), and the perfect distance (54mm) between the underside of the hook, and the top of the bed (I'll call it). Mark
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: It almost sounds like your getting some distortion in your prints. Have you tried printing a 20x20x20 calibration cube to see how close to 20mm your getting on each side?
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: What printer is this designed for? I have an Anet A8. The space between the X-rods is 46mm, center or rod to center of rod. The outside dimension is 54mm, top of rod to bottom of rod. Will this work?
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: I designed it to fit on my Anet A8 with the stock x carriage dimensions so it should fit your printer. The reason I designed this one instead of using one someone else already designed was my cheap dial indicator is smaller and wouldn't fit snug.
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: thanks, I hope your x-rods and mine are both 46mm apart. I bought a neotech dial gauge, which is also a bit smaller in size. The spigot is 8mm thought. Hopefully, that's the size of the hole in your unit. oh, well, if it's waste of filament, c-est lavie.
comments.author: oxarrogantxo

comments.text: I just double checked mine and my dial indicator has an 8mm shaft and my x carriage rods are 54mm outside to outside or 46mm center to center
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: sweet, that's what I needed, thank you very much!!!!!
comments.author: oxarrogantxo

comments.text: Your very welcome best of luck on your print!
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: Just finished carving on your design. The 8mm hole for my dial gauge, with a bit of carving, worked out fine. Sadly, the back spacing did not. Even with some carving, I'm measuring 52mm out to out on my rods with the design installed. With the design removed, I'm measuring the normal 54mm. There's nothing I can do with this piece. If I enlarge it in Cura, the hole will be enlarged also. Getting 2mm of spacing on the back will make the spigot hole far too large unless I wrap the spigot with tape. Better to ask you to adjust the rear spacing. The rear platform that goes under the lower x-bar needs to be 2mm lower. So there so go. On to another role of filament for me, as that print used 12 meters and three hours of my time. I do like this design though, and hope you can modify it to work on this Anet A8 that I have. Thanks!  Mark

comments.text: just edited and reuploaded the dial indicator mount under the label v2. also if you print with 3 perimeters and bottom and top layers and no infill you should cut your filament usage down to about 7.5 meters or 23 grams vs the 12 you used before and it should provide more than adequate support and stability. i hope this helps you out.

title: Rasperberry Pi Zero back cover (costumizable, with openSCAD-file)

description.text:
This is (or should be :-) a simple but to some degree customisable back cover for all versions of Raspberry Pi Zero. The uncustomized or default version will allmost look like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1836302 (which also inspired this thing - and might help you to turn your Pi Zero into an usb dongle which can share your PC's internet :-).

I wanted to be able to independently add and adjust overhang of the back cover on all four sides, e.g. to add coverage of the camera connector of Pi Zero v1.3 and Pi Zero W.

You should be able to adjust e.g.:

  • thickness of the plate
  • height and outer diameter of the mounts
  • radius and depth of the screw holes (up to completely "drilled" through)
  • independent overhang on all four sides

Users of OpenSCAD should also be able to further extend this thing on their own.

For STL-users I uploaded 2 STL-Files, one with a back cover size identical to Pi Zero, the other one on one side adds 1 millimeter for the overhang of the camera connector.

UPDATE 18.03.2017 UTC+1 (MEZ):
Updated comment usage to conventions of Thingiverse customizer (version ..._v1m02_customizer.scad). Customises better, but looks much uglier in OpenSCAD.

No other changes. Better human-readable openSCAD-file (..._v1m02.scad) also in the update. Original SCAD_upload deleted, since no differences than some unprecise comments.

I wanted to have a customisable cover, but also was curious to see the opportunities of the Thingiverse customizer.

Thus I wrote this OpenSCAD file from scratch. No magic in it. If you use the file with OpenSCAD the comments in the file might help you to adjust the back cover to your needs.

I designed this thing with OpenSCAD (exactly with OpenSCAD version 2017.03.16.nightly (git 714e14e) on an openSUSE Leap 42.1 Linux system :-).

For information regarding OpenSCAD see http://www.openscad.org/.

DISCLAIMER

This is my first uploaded thing ever. I really hope there are no bad surprises in it, but ... :-)

author: mabowat

description.text:
Great design by timrbsnow.
This model has an design if it's waiting to go to action.

But i like motion. So i used the original files (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069981) to create legs that are flexed. This gives more dynamic to this nice ATAT.

I adjusted the base file, so the leg pins are a little longer.

The base has longer pins. Fit the legs. The pins will sticking out of the legs. And use a welding torch to heat the pins, the will melt and this gives a solid fixture to the base. When the material is cooling down. Position the legs , like you desire.

The headpiece can be adjusted as well. Heat the triangulaire part, just enough to make the part a little flexible. Push the head into the body and position it as you like.

i used meshmixer to adjust the legs, sketchup to make the pins of the body larger.
And 3D builder to make the parts manifold. Meshmixer can do this to, but sometimes the end result is not as nice as i wanted to be.

title: Kodama Trinus E3D v6 mod v1

description.text:
There is no need to talk about the E3D v6, it is a state of the art reference hot end, you won´t get a better one.

What is the use of the mod, what are the differences compared to the trinus hot end:

  • Even the E3D v6 has a PTFE inliner, it is a full metal hot end and at the time being only the trinus firmware limits its max temperature.
  • No PTFE degradation, no changing extrusion problems over time
  • No unstable extrusion/retraction problems, printing speed is only limited by trinus resonance problems and not by the hot/cold end extrusion capacity, I print PETG infill at 230 °C 0.2mm and 80-100 mm/s, before the mod I struggled to achieve 20 mm/s without problems, 80-100 mm/s will only make sense for some prints on such a small build volume, but it makes a huge difference if you print at e.g. 60-80 mm/s in average than compared to <20 mm/s.
  • Reliable consistent extrusion, not sometime it works and sometimes not
  • Much quicker heat up time, better temperature control after PID autotune,
  • with same heater cartridge higher printing temperatures are possible –but right now they are anyhow limited by the firmware
  • If the fan blows fully to the nozzle, the temperature drops, but much less
  • At same printing speeds no bleeding edges, bleeding edges occur much later at much higher printing speeds
  • If you need spare parts you can get them everywhere (nozzles, heat block, heat break….), quick and cheap, no need to wait for Kodama
  • no jams/clogging (it is still possible depending on what you do, but only if you do something wrong and not because it is a misconstruction)
  • much better fan duct (evenness of air flow)
  • reduction of moving masses
  • more easy maintenance, no black box which blocks sight

#######################################################################
What you need:

  1. E3d v6 1.75mm Universal (normal version with small heat block, not the upgraded heat block) with 100k thermistor. Other name is e.g. "E3D v6 1.75 long distance with PTFE"
    The mod was done with the OLD E3D v6, that means with the small heat block and NOT with the new bigger heat block sold since mid 2016. E3D v6 clones use the old heat block.
    The thermistor as well as the heater cartridge fits for the trinus.
    Why did I use the old one ? Because I had the old version and I don´t see any real advantage for the customer of the new one. It is bigger (and there is not much space for the mod) and is made for a PT100 thermometer or special (more expensive) thermistors.
    So if you want to use the moded fan duct, you need the small heat block. E3D v6 clones are available for < 5 Euro, the heat block for < 1 Euro, so that shouldn´t be a problem.
    I don´t say you should buy clones or cloned parts at all, as well as I don´t say you are a bad guy doing it. There are 1.75 mm E3D v6 clones available without PTFE - don´t use them !
    It there are request for the v6 new version, I will adapt the mod.
    For assembly see here https://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/E3D-v6_Assembly#HotSide
  2. E3D cold end fan including duct (should be part of the E3D v6 order) or you use the existing 40mm trinus cold end fan, which i recommend
  3. PTFE tube 4/2 mm, some cms, in principle it even works without, but i don´t recommend without.
  4. the thingiverse 3D printed parts shown in the pictures above.

Optional parts

  • Thermal paste to use in between the E3D heatbreak and the round cooling body
  • Cardboard or Insulation cotton to insulate the nozzle and as air shield
  • Spare parts, e.g. if I change the nozzle for a print, i just change the whole hot end, because the clones are anyhow very cheap

#######################################################################
assembly:

  • remove/disassemble the trinus hot end cold end, strip it down until only the alu-block and mounted extruder remains, according to https://www.kodamaforums.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=22&t=1721 remove parts L, H, M, N. All other parts on the picture can remain.
  • remove also the plate which is screwed onto the x-carriage. The part "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate" gets directly screwed to the x-carriage
  • mount the part "filament_guide_extruder" and the alu-extruder block. Use the 2 existing worm screws to fix it
  • prepare the 4/2mm PTFE tube and cut it to about 49 mm, push the PTFE tube into the assembled E3D v6, you will need to push it really "hard" to get it into the heatbreak of the E3D. To other end of the PTFE tube is inserted into the "filament path" of the alu/extruder and by that pushed into the end of the part filament_guide_extruder. If necessary adjust the length of the PTFE tube, but 49 mm should fit about +-1mm. If the 49mm seems to be much too long, then you probably didn´t push it into the heatbrake - so push harder;)
  • The E3D including the PTFE tube should now be fitted to the extruder alu-block.
  • screw the extruder block to the part "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate" and press the E3D into its snap fit
  • the E3D snap fit is quite tight, maybe you need to put it to a table and press it into it, when doing my tests, the E3D was mounted without the part "E3D_bracket" (so it works even without), but you should mount it now. Be careful and look which side of the "E3D bracket" needs to be up
  • mount the fan duct of your choice including the 5015 trinus to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate" using the hole which fixes the fan duct to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate"
  • use the upper hole to screw the other end of the 5015 fan to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate"
  • rotate the fan duct to its end position and snap it onto the 5015 fan
  • check the distance between fan duct and bed, when the nozzle touches the bed, it should be exactly 2mm
  • mount the cold end fan, if you want to use the trinus 40 mm fan, you have to print the part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D"

  • use the holes for the zip ties to zip cables as you like

  • the removed screws of the trinus can be used, you don´t need additional screws, the M3 small screws are used to mount the extruder/alu-block, the bigger M4 screws to mount the 5015 fan and the M3 worm screws are used tofix the filament guide
  • you will propably need to rewire connectors of the E3D cold fan, or better, use the 40mm trinus fan ("trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D")

######################################################################
IMPORTANT:

  • Before you use the E3D v6, you need to change the PID-tuning with gcode commands, e.g. with M106 S255; M303 S200; see here http://www.kodamaforums.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=1762
  • readjust your z-end stop

######################################################################
Because the trinus has an 4010 cold end fan, it is an advantage to use it also as E3D cold end fan instead of the standard E3D 30mm cold end fan e.g. --> part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D"

######################################################################
Maintenance position:
In order ot change nozzles and so on, the fan duct can be easily rotated by 180 ° to give free access to the nozzle/hetaer block, see very last right picture above.

######################################################################
3D printed Parts:
all parts can be printed without supports, i used 3 outlines and 15 % infill, works with 0.4 and 0.5 mm nozzle and various filaments

  1. "Filament_guide_extruder"
    • Optional, in principle stiff filaments work also without, but there is no disadvantage to use it
    • can be printed in every filament
    • i would prefer 0.1 mm layer height, but it works also with e.g. 0.2
  2. "E3D_extruder_fan_mounting_plate"
    • PLA might not work, or only for low print temperatures (200°C), at least PETG, BDP, ABS, ASA or filaments with high heat resistance
    • 0.1 -0.2 mm layer height
    • If you use PLA increase number of outer lines to 4/5 and solid top/bottom layers to e.g. 5* 0.2 mm
    • Infill about >=15%, according to number of top layers and material
  3. "E3D_bracket"
    • Use filament with at least same heat resistance as 3
    • 0.1 -0.2 mm layer height
    • It is the only part which could be printed using supports, I don´t use supports, this gives some unwanted bridges on the horizontal overhang, which can be removed easily afterward, so no supports needed
  4. fan ducts
    • Use a filament with the highest possible heat resistance, PLA might work for a certain time, I use extrudr BDP which survives about 115 °C without problems
    • like all other circular fan ducts, if the nozzle is close to the bed, the air gets redirected towards the nozzle/heater block, this can lead to
      -> Additional cooling load for the cold end (increased risk of jamming), therefore block hot air flow by air shield or mount bigger cold end fan, or increase PSU-Voltage
      -> Temperature increase for the base plate (PLA might get problems), therefore block air flow by air shield or mount bigger cold end fan, or increase PSU-Voltage
      -> Temperature drops when operating at high temperatures close to the bed, therefore block air flow by air shield already before the nozzle, use cotton insulation of the nozzle
      To prevent this, I tested different fan duct designs and ended with the 2 following
    • "fan_duct_cold_filaments" (PLA) , a fan duct for low-temperature filament, hot air redirection isn´t that big problem because of the lower temperature, can be used with or without hot air shield
    • "fan_duct_hot_filaments" for higher temp filaments with included air shield, prevents air going upwards towards the heater block and above, material is very close to the nozzle/heater block, so it will get shiny, but that doesn´t matter, this design gives less maximum air flow than the other, but in general high temp filaments need less air flow.
    • the fan duct design was optimized for evenness of airflow from all directions, design verified with CFD simulation, the target was not to maximize air flow, because this also can disturb the print, it should direct the cold air exactly where it is needed, therefore much less airflow is needed compared to not circular fan ducts
  5. trinus 40mm cold end fan
    The E3D should come with a 30 mm cold end fan, which is fine, but the 40 mm trinus fan will provide even better cooling, if you want to use the triuns fan print the part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D". Another advantage of the trinus fan is, that the electric connectors will fit for sure.
  6. hot air shield (not 3Dprinted)
    • Optional, depending on your needs, if you notice temperature drops when close to the bed, or too high cold end temperatures you should block the air moving upwards
    • The hot air shield can easily be made of insulation cotton or recycled cardboard or metal, if you are more ambitious. All you need to do is to put e.g. a piece of cardboard between the E3D heat block and the E3D cold on cooling block. If the air cannot move upward, it is not influencing the cold end or heater block anymore.
    • Used with lower temp fan duct, to prevent air getting towards the heater block/cold end

#######################################################################
Pictures from left to right

  1. mod in real life with 40 mm cold end fan mounted
  2. mod in real life with 40 mm cold end fan mounted
  3. mod in real life with 40 mm cold end fan mounted
  4. Overview, 40mm fan, extruder/alu block and filament guide not shown
  5. mounting plate for E3D, 5015 hot end fan and fan duct and extruder alu-block
  6. fan duct for higher temperature filaments (> 200 -220 °C)
  7. fan duct for lower temperature filaments
  8. mounting bracket for E3D
  9. filament guide for extruder alu-block
  10. trinus 40 mm cold end fan mount, instead of standard 30 mm E3D fan
  11. Overview, 40 mm fan, extruder/alu block and filament guide not shown, fan rotated to maintenance position

#######################################################################
Outlook and improvement potential

  • Optimize hot air management further
  • Improve sight to 1st layer --> modify fan duct further
  • Move nozzle a few mm up, this needs to change the fan design
  • Maybe reduce weight further by exchanging the extruder block with 3D printed parts
  • If some wants add a casing

#######################################################################
If one needs some small mods of the mod, i could probably change it.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2 mm

Infill:

15 %

GeoFabLab presented their latest creation: TouchTerrain!

http://touchterrain.geol.iastate.edu/

TouchTerrain is a new, free, open-source web application for downloading 3D printable terrain models for anywhere on Earth.

TouchTerrain Details TouchTerrain utilizes Google Earth Engine and a simplified Google Maps-style interface to access 10m NED elevation data in the US, 30m SRTM data for most of the Earth ±60° from the equator and above sea-level, and ETOPO 1km data for the entire planet (including seafloor bathymetry!). TouchTerrain can adjust terrain models before they are downloaded in a number of ways. It can exaggerate the Z to bring out the details in subtle topographies. It can tile large areas to be printed on a smaller build plates. It can adjust the resolution of the model so it matches your printer's capabilities. That way you don't overwhelm your slicer or printer with more data than it can handle. Models can be 3D printed on your own equipment or uploaded to service companies like Shapeways.com. The models included above represent Crater Lake, Sheep Mountain (In Wyoming near the Iowa State Univ Geology Field Camp) and Ames, Iowa (home to Iowa State University). GeoFabLab is Dr. Franek Hasiuk and Dr. Chris Harding in the Geology Program at Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa, USA. E-mail [email protected] with questions, comments, and suggestions!

3D Print a Terrain Model

  • Go to TouchTerrain (http://touchterrain.geol.iastate.edu/) on a computer or mobile device.

  • Use the GoogleMaps-stlye interface to find a part of the earth that is interesting to you. If you can't think of a place just yet, try going to part of the Grand Canyon in Northern Arizona.

  • Click "Re-center box in current view". This will bring the selection box to where you have traveled to.

  • Click "Export", which will take you to a new page listing the parameters you have picked for your model

  • Now click "Submit" and TouchTerrain will build your model. It may not seem like anything is happening, but in a few seconds to a few minutes, your should see a new page that gives you a link to download your model.

  • Download your model.

  • Open you model in a program capable of reading STL files (for example, Meshlab, Makerbot, or Meshmixer) or upload it to service companies like Shapeways.com or Viewstl.com.

  • 3D Print your model.

  • Use your model to communicate with others about a piece of the earth or to learn something yourself about it!
Computer, 3D Printer or funds for printing 3D models through a service company

• Geography
  • Geology
  • Orienteering
  • Environmental Science
  • Geodesy
  • Love of Earth
Minimum 10 minutes

description.text:
Designed in Fusion 360
My second ever design in the programm
New lighter frame for my Revell X-SPY
for 8.5mm motors

Here are some plane curves, hypocycloids, made three dimensional by extending them along the z axis as was done for the epicycloids in thing:217201 - Epicycloids as Mobils. Hypocycloids and epicycloids are closely related; a single sign change in the parametric equations for an epicycloid changes it to a hypocycloid. Like the epicycloid the hypocycloid can have multiple cusps; 3 cusps is a deltoid, 4 cusps is an astroid, 5, 6, 7, etc. cusps are possible and a circle occurs when the number of cusps approaches infinity. Stl files are: deltoid_mark_1.stl
astroid_mark_2.stl
hypocycloid_mark_3.stl
hypocycloid_mark_4.stl
hypocycloid_mark_5.stl
deltoid_mark_6.stl The openSCAD code allows one to choose between epicycloids, hypocycloids, single sided models and double sided models.

The single sided files can be printed directly on the build surface.  
The examples shown in the image above are the result of gluing two single sided prints together.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Filament Holder Tube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wasn't too happy about the original holder that comes with the Prusa i3 Mk2, since you have to move the holders to accommodate different width spools of filament. So I designed a tube that fits between the holders. The tube is 90mm long, so it fits Prusa spools or narrower.

v2 is designed with an oversized internal diameter (0.5 mm clearance), which gives a nice fit on the Prusa holder arms, as well as chamfered edges for easier insertion. It also has a 3 mm smaller outer diameter to keep spools from trying to roll of it (the outside diameter of the Prusa holders are 25mm in diameter).

v3 is a longer version, 100mm, which clears the 90mm Prusa spools nicely.

Print it upright with a 3 mm brim since it's very tall and narrow!

The filament guide is this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1708213

author: triton_9

description.text:
Overview

Storage for the minis and cards from the Flying Frog Productions Game: Shadows of Brimstone. These boxes were designed to fit into the original "coffin" box for the base game, and the cards I stick into the Cave of Cynder expansion.

After getting the game, and building & painting all of the minis, I needed a good way to 1) store them, and 2) carry them to the location of the game night so that my gaming group and I could play. At first this consisted of lots of Plano storage boxes, and Ultra-Pro Deck boxes, but, since I could 3D print stuff.... Why not.

I broke out sketchup and after some pretty quick quick work with calipers and a bunch of printing, I have a nice modular storage that also helps to keep stuff organized on the table during play. Sure, it might not be as nice as a huge army of baddies waiting the wings of the mines, but then again at midnight when cleanup begins its pretty nice that it all goes back into the box nicely and quickly.

Mini Storage

So, if you want to actually fit the stuff for the game into the game boxes, print out the stuff below. After building all of these storage boxes, and some more for the Trederra (coming soon) I still have more room in the box for other expansions that I have yet to acquire :)

City of the Ancients (Core set 1):

  • 2 40mm (x6) short boxes - Void Spiders (12)
  • 2 31mm x 61mm (x3) boxes - Void Tentacles (6)
  • 1 40mm (x6) boxes - Stranglers (6)
  • 1 50mm (x3) boxes - Night Terrors (3)
  • 1 30mm (x6) boxes - Heros (4)

Swamps of Death (Core Set 2):

  • 3 30mm (x6) boxes - Heros + Hungry Dead (12)
  • 3 50mm (x3) boxes - Slashers (3) + Hell Bats (6)
  • 2 31mm x 61mm (x3) boxes - Void Tentacles (6)

Caves of Cynder Otherworld Expansion:

  • 1 50mm (x3) box - Lava Men (3)

Masters of the Void Expansion:

  • 1 50mm x 81mm (x3) box - Void Hounds (3)
  • 1 31mm x 61mm (x3) box - Void mages (3)

Hell Vermin Expansion:

  • 1 50mm (x3) box - Hell Vermin (3)

Trederra Otherworld Deluxe Expansion:

  • Coming Soon!

Cards

For the card storage I used the box from the Caves of Cynder expansion, but the modular boxes also fit nicely in the core set coffin boxes too.

I used a total of 14 card boxes split as below:

  • 1 box for Gear
  • 1 box for Mine Map cards
  • 1 box for Mine Encounter Cards
  • 1 box for each Otherworld. (each contains Maps, Encounters, Artifacts, and threats).
  • 1 Box for darkness/Growing Dread cards
  • 1 box for Mine Artifacts, Loot, and Scavenge cards
  • 1 box for Elite and High Threats
  • 1 box for Medium and Low threats
  • 1 box for Rule cards
  • 1 box for Hero cards, Starting Items, and Personal Items
  • 1 box for Trederra special cards.

author: 3DPrintedAspie

description.text:
I intend to use these to clamp accessories to my Taig mill, but this can be used to print t-nuts of any size. In the photo, I show t-nuts sized for a Taig mill, and also a much larger Bridgeport. The scad file uses aubenc's threading library (http:www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796). The default sizes are for a Taig t-slot, and all dimensions are in units of inches (sorry rest of the world...). Nevertheless, with some unit conversion on your part, metric threads shouldn't be a problem.  
Note well: these are NOT intended for machining! Plastic is much weaker than steel, and it doesn't take a lot of clamping force to shatter the t-nut. Use these for lighter applications like holding down measurement fixtures or chip-guards.
I printed these t-nuts on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using medium (0.2mm) resolution, and the threads work well without any cleanup.

print_settings.Notes:: IMPORTANT - the cones below the barbell ends of the old-fashioned-tap-like bolt head are support material. They tend to snap off as you take them off the build plate - that's the idea!

IMPORTANT - the cones below the barbell ends of the old-fashioned-tap-like bolt head are support material. They tend to snap off as you take them off the build plate - that's the idea!
Tiny amount of cleanup may be needed other than snapping off those cones. You may have to fettle the hole a tad.
This is a small part of my soon-to-be-released Phoba mobile phone car mount which I thought would be of general use

I have a ladder at my campervan for use inside to get to the bed. I have used it before outside at the side of the van with towels around the upper part not to damage anything.

For that I made this thing. It consists of two parts. A clip that is put into the hooks at the top of the ladder and a plate that is put onto the clip. The plates are identical for both sides. The clips must be printed normal and mirrored. At least that was my shortsighted intention. But of course you can use both parts symmetrically, too.
I will put some foam on the plates not to damage the ouutside of the campervan.

This ladder was (is?) used with Carado campervans and probably several other types.

Printer:

Renkforce RF100

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The clip needs supports. The plate does not. I printed it with 100% because the design is quite hollowed. But I think it wouldn't be necessary for strength.
I had severe problems with warping with the plate. Do everything your printer needs.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a 3D printable pair of glasses offered by https://VirtualTryOn.fr, a web solution which allows opticians to customize eyeglass frames, so that they perfectly fit the faces of their customers.
You can find here a curved version of the same model : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2186468
Please feel free to talk about VirtualTryOn.fr to your optician !

comments.text:
As an Optometrist, we had a joke about 3D printed specs at work, so when the opportunity presented, we made some.
They looked the deal alright. Until we attempted to assemble.
And both arm joints shattered, then broke off completely. First one side, then the second.
There is no strength in the joint, I'm afraid. If they break with assembly, even using a proper heat unit, it'll never last in real use.
However, we didn't give up on it completely.
We're going to fit a rivet hinge set used in Rayban style specs, and see if it holds up.
Is this practical in real life?
Obviously not. Would be a fraction of the price just buying something cheap frame-wise online.
But it's too much fun to give up yet....

author: Teljemo

title: Creality CR-10 Ball bearings filament roll support

description.text:
This is a filament spool support for the CR-10 that complements the stock one. It uses ball bearings and has 2 lateral guides.

This is definitely not a must have upgrade for the CR-10. You can consider it only if you had a print ruined by a spool problem.

The aim was to secure prints that last very long by limiting the risk that something goes wrong due to the filament spool.

The filament spool rolls on the ball bearings. The force required from the extruder to pull the filament is minimum and the movement is very smooth. The two lateral guides are there to prevent the filament spool to shift or tangle on the axis.

The system is designed for spools with a hole of dia 52mm or above.

The bearing used have an internal diameter of 5mm, an external diameter of 16mm and a thickness of 5mm (625 type). You need 4 of them.

To have the complete set, you need to print 4 "Bearing support" and 2 "Lateral guide".

Take 2 bearing supports, install one bearing on each, put them together and clip the assembly on the original spool holder axis. Do that twice to have the two support. You should be able to slide the supports to adjust their location.

The lateral guides are installed as shown on the picture. If your axis has the same diameter as mine (30.3 mm), they will be really tight. This was on purpose. This idea is that you sand the inside of the hole so that you can move them on the axis but there is still a significant friction that prevent them to slide.

Use the stock nut to secure everything (but be careful not block the rotation of the spool with the lateral guides).

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

20%

author: KrabDaddy

title: Motorcycle Throttle Wrist Rest
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After going on a two day 520 mile tour on my motorcycle, I decided I needed to make myself a wrist rest to remove some of the strain on my throttle hand.  And why buy one when I have a 3d printer, and could make my own!
LICENSE: I'm releasing this as non-commercial.  If you'd like to print and sell these commercially I'm open to individual/one-off licenses allowing that.

Print and install on the throttle twist grip. This is sized for a 2000 ninja 250, which has grips that are approx. 1.3 inches in diameter. It is a tight fit on these grips. MATERIAL: I printed this in ABS. I'm not sure this will work in PLA since it needs to be fairly springy in order to be installed. The springiness of the material is also what makes it stay in position. PRINT SETTINGS: I strongly recommend using >2 perimeters and >50% infill on this part, since it is under constant load, and the more spring force the part generates the better it will stay in place. No retention features other than friction are needed to keep it in place - the downward pressure from your palm tightens the band/clamp portion against the grip. INSTALLATION: The rest should be snapped onto the outer end of the twist grip, with the palm rest sitting very gently against the palm of your hand when the throttle is in the idle position. Make sure it does not interfere with your ability to close the throttle and find the front brakes. The important thing is that it not be so high that it causes the throttle to be held open when your palm is in your neutral position. I've attached a few pictures showing the installation on my bike relative to my neutral hand position. The angle of the picture is a bit weird but it should give you a starting point. FIELD RESULTS: This works satisfactorily. I ended up adjusting it slightly lower than I had it initially. It provides adequate support that I can maintain/adjust throttle position without holding onto the throttle with my fingers at all. It also does not interfere with more "spirited" riding, which is good. All-in-all I'm pretty satisfied with the results.

comments.text: The ninja 250 is an amazing bike, especially if you get the 88-2006? model. So many available parts, bullet proof as long as you take care of it. I miss mine a lot 2004 - yellow, 20K miles in 3 years as my primary mode of transportation. Even rode in several inches of snow in UT! I did a non stop on my 250 from Provo, UT to Sacramento, CA (10.5 hrs) and then a non stop from Provo, UT to Mesa, AZ (13 hrs in the dark). I could have used this thingy then :)

author: crispy

description.text: UPDATED January 4th I made more room for X-axis travel and should be the full 175mm of X-axis of travel. Sorry to those who downloaded the original version and printed. You may be able to trim the ExtruderClamp like version 2 on the side that gets near the X-axis motor pulley. This is a belt clamp for the QU-BD 2Up/One Up extruder. This is to avoid the use of glue to attach the extruder to the belt. It has worked well for me. NOTE: I have not tested it on a One Up printer. Assembly: Looking at the extruder back side (belt side) I attached the extruder belt clamp with a M4 by 8mm long cap screw into the hole on the left side. The M4 will self-thread into the MDF and hold it secure without interfering with the Filament spring loaded clamp 3/8-16 button head cap screw. Let the right side remain unattached while attaching the extruder assembly to the two linear bearings on X-axis gantry. Once the extruder is attached to the X-axis gantry linear bearings then close the clamp onto the belt and then use a M3 by 8mm long cap head screw (or equivalent) and thread into the hole of the printed clamp.

I have printed it at .25mm layer height and .20% infill with only one perimeter (or wall) using PLA material. I printed with the flat side on the build plateform not as it is shown in the 3D STL model view.

comments.text: This resolves a serious design flaw in the 1up and 2up and is an excellent design.  Why q3 cheaped out on such a critical component I'll never know.  I ended ended up using an m3 and nut on the locking end.

author: metaled

description.text: Just a quick sketch of a keychain idea I did in Solidworks of the grill of my Jeep Liberty KK

title: Geared Lazy Susan, Robotic Arm Project

description.text:
Where's Everything Else???

https://www.thingiverse.com/Gear_Down_For_What/collections/robotic-arm
In This Collection you will find:
  • All other related parts for this project
  • Future Updates to this Project
  • All User Submitted Remix's
  • Click that watch button to get notifications on future uploads!

Special Instructions For The Gearbox's <- Important!

You can use whichever gearbox that you want, as long as it's listed in the collection above.

Parts Needed
  • For this joint, you only need "Ring Gears #1", "Ring Gear#2" and the "3 Module Planet Gears"
  • Do NOT use the "4 Module planet gears" they are too long.
  • Do NOT use "Ring Rear #3"
Explanation
  • The 3rd module of the gearbox will go seemingly unused inside the top cover but it will actually be supporting top end of the planet gears. Though there IS room for the #3 ring gear to be installed, it would not support much of anything and only cause additional drag, backlash, and make this base impossible to disassemble.

Required Hardware

  • (2) 6/32's or 4mm bolts 55mm long
  • (8) short 3mm bolts to hold the stepper motor in place
  • 4.5mm BB's for a BB gun

Attachment Method

  • Please Read Section "A and B"
  • To attach to this, use the EZ print Design or newer and make sure you use this custom center ring holder.
  • The bullet-looking spacers go into the holes and work to hold all of the pieces in tight alignment.

A and B?

  • The "Rotating Base" has an "A" style connection, so a "B" Style Connection is required to attach to it.
  • Connections with a stepper motor mount are considered "A" Style connections.
  • It's an unavoidable compatibility problem that arose from the recent simplification of the design. Opposite's attract, "A" style connections only mate with "B" style connections and "B" style connections only mate with "A" style connections.

Other Important Info:

Electronics, Firmware?!?
  • Program that I use is here: https://github.com/GearDownForWhat/RobotArm
  • I run this on an Arduino DUE with a CNC shield and DRV8825 Stepper drivers.
CAD Files??

  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2w9v9bw

  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, then I'll add them to my main collection so the whole community can share them! Thanks!
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What? We are a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for us to earn fees by linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites.

description.text:
"Fight for life on the planet Earth,
Defend all human beings, even the ones that you don't understand,
Believe in love that is out of anyone's control,
And then risk everything for it!" [Manifesto of Rose Quartz]

The Crystal Gems, also referred to as the Rebels, are a group of Gems established by Rose Quartz who, unlike the rest of their kind, seek to protect the Earth instead of exploiting it and are the self-proclaimed guardians of humanity. Their title as the "Crystal Gems" distinguishes them from the Homeworld Gems.

Members:

  • Garnet
  • Ruby
  • Sapphire
  • Rose Quartz
  • Pearl
  • Amethyst
  • Peridot
  • Steven
  • Lapis Lazuli
  • Bismuth

- Author's Note -

At last, my full set of Crystal Gems is completed. Now the next step is to complete the other remaining sets and then I can move to the wearable variant of Gems.

description.text:
Printed a universal filament holder for my 2016 Creator Pro but there was a gap between the spool and the back of the printer. Filament would come off the spool and wrap around the holder. I couldn't find a filament guide that appeared to work with my 2016 model so I made this one up. I've run a couple of prints with it and everything seems to be working fine.

Actually, after having done this, I see that guides that at first glance I didn't think they were for the 2015 are. I guess that make this YAFG.

author: yuh1973

description.text:
If you'd like one of these (fully assembled, kit, or printed parts only) check out my 3D Hub. Just a note on orders, I no longer make these with the vinyl as it was just too much of a pain to work with.

UPDATE: Oops, made the walls on the ear clip too thin, fixed.
UPDATE 2: Wow, the typos! And those instructions didn't make much sense, haha. Hopefully its better now.
UPDATE 3: Vinyl and lighting test pictures uploaded. Modifying the shells to hold the LED/Battery now. See below (Step 7) for pictures and parts used.
Update 4: Ok, final version for now. Changed quite a bit. Typing this up late at night, so sorry for any typos or anything I may have missed.
Update 5: I've added two solid versions without space for the electronics. One is just one solid piece and a clip with no spaces for magnets. Just print, paint, and glue the ear clip on. The other has the focus in two pieces with space for the magnets in the top part, but is otherwise solid. Print those and the clip with magnet spots and off you go!
Update 6: I've been including some better instructions with the kits I sell, and figured I should probably just put those here as well! Sorry if I missed some reference to a part I include in the kit, I just copied and pasted it over and may have missed something when editing it for this page.
Update 7: Removed the design files.

This is Aloy's focus from the game Horizon: Zero Dawn.

I made this as close as I could to accurate dimensions using screen shots. I also added details to the bottom that were inspired by the Focus prop that came with the special edition of the game. I haven't seen any screenshots of the bottom of the in game model and haven't seen the bottom of the thing while playing, but I didn't want to leave the bottom just a flat surface. The special edition prop is horribly inaccurate in dimensions and overall design (its not even close), but the detail on the bottom is cool so I adapted it to fit the bottom of my design to give it a little extra flare.

This is intended to use magnets to clip to the included ear piece. It also uses magnets to hold the two shells together. There is a small battery and blue LED inside to give it that authentic look.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You only need support for the top shell.
It may be possible to print at a lower resolution, but details on bottom may not come out well.
Print the "bar" at 0.2mm layer height with a transparent filament.
I recommend printing everything else in black.

Assembly

Its pretty simple to put this all together, but here's some instructions to help you out!
You will need eight 1/8" diameter x 1/16" thick neodymium disc magnets. I use these grade N52 magnets from K&J because they are super strong and you can buy boat loads of them on the cheap: D21B-N52

For the LED, I used these

Power provided with one of these CR927 Batteries. And just to let you know, I left the battery in for more than 24 hours while testing and have been popping it in and out of various versions of this thing as I've worked and it is still glowing brightly. Should be more than enough for any cosplay!

If you'd like to try it out, in the past I've used this vinyl

Lastly, you'll need super glue (I use gel super glue) and some kind of epoxy putty. I prefer "Green Stuff" as I'm just used to using it for modeling and such. I buy this, 3 feet of the stuff lasts forever.

Smoothing

The first thing you want to do is smooth the top shell of the focus. There are a couple of ways to do this, but the gist is coating the Focus in something and then sanding. For coating you can either use a Filler Primer (I use Rust-Oleum Filler Primer) or liquid super glue (I use Loctite Professional Liquid, but any liquid cyanoacrylate glue should work). I prefer to use the super glue method, as it gives the surface a nice hard shell that is easy to get super smooth. The filler primer is easier to sand, but you may have to do a couple cycles of spraying, sanding, spraying, sanding to get a good result. The choice is yours.

If you choose to use the filler primer, just spray the top shell, wait for it to dry completely, and sand (more on the sanding later). If needed, spray again, let it dry and sand again. Repeat until as smooth as you want.

For the super glue method, you’ll want to stick the top shell to something you can hold (don’t want to glue your fingers to it!). Just use a pill bottle, small modeling paint pot, or something of a similar size. Use some blue poster tack or tape and stick it on there. Cover the whole shell in a thin layer of glue. Let it dry overnight if you can and resist the urge to touch it! Once it dries you may notice the glue pulled away from some spots. Just cover them and let them dry again. Now you can sand. Note that using this method takes a bit more sanding, but it evens out in the end with the multiple coats you usually have to do with the primer.

Now for the most tedious part, the sanding. You want to get some 400 grit and 600 grit wet/dry sandpaper. You don’t want to go any lower than 400 grit as it’ll take off material too fast and you might sand a hole in your focus. You’ll want to wet sand. I usually just stand at the kitchen sink, tear off a piece of sandpaper about the size of my palm, turn the water to a small dribble and work under the running water. Start with the 400 grit, sanding in a circular motion. Go for about 30 seconds at a time, check your progress before continuing. Make sure to get the sides and back of the shell too. Keep going until you get it nice and smooth. Then, do one last sanding with the 400 grit, but this time, instead of a circular motion, just sand back and forth, perpendicular to the slot. This will make sure that any tiny scratches in the final surface all go in one direction, giving that brushed metal look in the end. Next, take your 600 grit paper and wet sand again perpendicular to the slot. Lastly, put a piece of your 400 grit paper on a flat surface, like your counter. You can put some paper towels under it to soak up any mess. Put a bit of water on it and sand the bottom shell by pressing it onto this paper on the counter. That’ll make sure the bottom stays nice and flat. Do this again with the 600 grit paper. You may also need to sand the edges of the bottom shell a tiny bit, but it isn’t all that noticeable if you skip that. After all of that you’ll finally be ready for painting!

Painting

Ok, I’m by no means an expert painter, and there’s probably a million ways to do this part, but this is how I’ve been doing it. I use Rub n Buff Silver Leaf. If you have any interest in Cosplay, you’ll love this stuff. It’ll make anything look like metal. It’s basically a wax paint with metal powder in it. It even buffs up nice and shiny like real metal. If you use this, you’ll need a cotton rag too. I just use old t-shirts cut into dishrag sized squares. Avoid using any parts that have printed designs as those will scratch your surface. Put a little dollop on the rag (and I mean a little, this stuff spreads easily) and work it into the top shell. Don’t mess with it too much once its on and apply more as needed to get full coverage. You want it to be layered fairly thick so it can withstand handling, but it’s kind of hard to describe just how much you want on there. Don’t worry though, this part is pretty impossible to mess up. Just try not to get any on the inside of the shell or in the slot. Once you think you’ve got it, let it dry for a bit and then buff it real well with a rag. Try to buff perpendicular to the slot just like when sanding to emphasize that brushed metal look, and don’t forget the sides and back of the shell. If you get some thin spots that don’t look like they have enough coverage after buffing, just add another layer of rub n buff and let it dry/buff it again. Also, at this point you may notice some defects in the surface of your focus that you missed during sanding. If they bother you, you can go back to sanding again. No need to put more glue on or clean off the Rub n Buff. Just sand it down smooth and try doing the Rub n Buff process again. This took me 4 tries with my first one, so don’t get too frustrated if you have to repeat again! You can also apply the rub n buff to the bottom of the bottom shell at this point. Try to go a little lighter on the application here so it doesn’t get into the detail lines. If it does, don’t panic, you can fix it. Try running the back edge of a razor blade down the line to clear it out. If that doesn’t work you can either use a super fine Sharpie or some black acrylic paint on a thin brush to clean up the lines later. This part will be against your head, so it’s up to you how careful you want to be here. If you want to add a bit more detail, get some gold acrylic paint and carefully paint in all of the little triangles on the bottom. At this point, you’ll probably have a bit of silver Rub n Buff on the inside surfaces of both shells. Cover these with a black sharpie or some black acrylic paint. Now, the thing with Rub n Buff is it doesn’t seem like it ever fully dries, so you’ll get a slightly shiny look to your fingers every time you handle the focus too much. In theory, you could probably use some spray on clear coat to stop this, but I’ve never tried it as I want to have the ability to buff the focus in the future.

Keep in mind, the amount of effort you want to put into this smoothing and painting is entirely up to you. If this all seems daunting, remember you can always just give it a light sanding to smooth out the overly rough areas and just paint the whole thing silver with acrylic paint and be done with it.

Next up is final assembly!

The Magnets

Ok, now you are going to want to have some Gel Super glue. I use Loctite as that’s what Walmart has, but any GEL super glue should work. Get 3 magnets. Put a small drop of glue into each of the “cups” on the bottom shell. Be careful not to put in too much, you don’t want a lot oozing out. Put a magnet into each cup. Let the glue dry completely. When dry, put another magnet onto each of the three in the cups (no glue just let them magnetize to each other to make sure the poles are facing correctly. This is where you are going to use that epoxy putty (the yellow/blue clay looking stuff, also called green stuff) for the first time. Keep a small cup of water handy when using the green stuff to keep it from sticking to your fingers. Just dip your fingers whenever the putty starts to get too tacky to work with. Cut off a small piece of the putty so that you have an equal amount of yellow and blue. Mash it together, keeping your fingers wet, until the blob is an even green color. Put a tiny drop of your gel super glue on the top magnet of each of your magnet pairs in the bottom shell. Now take small pieces about the size of one of the magnets and put them onto the top of your magnet stacks. You need a blob big enough so that when you put the top shell onto all of this, the blob will squish into the underside of the top shell, forming a cup for the upper magnet on the top shell. Now, put a drop of glue on top of the green stuff. So, going from bottom to top, in each cup you’ll now have: Bottom of the cup, Glue, Magnet #1, Magnet #2, Glue, Green stuff blob, glue. Once you’ve got green stuff on each stack, put the top shell on. Make sure all of the edges of both shells are lined up and use either a weak clamp or some light object to keep the whole thing squeezed together. Let the green stuff set up for at least 8 hours. Once set, you should have two shells held together with magnets! There’s a chance that one of the top magnets will come out of its green stuff cup, just glue it back in if this happens, making sure your poles are facing the right way.

Now for the ear clip. Take your last two magnets and let them magnetize to the underside of the bottom shell. Use a marker (Sharpie or whatever else) to mark the face of each magnet not stuck to the focus. Now, glue these into the cups on your ear clip, using the marks you made to keep the poles facing right (the marked face should be inside the cup). Keep in mind the Focus is meant to be worn on the right ear when you are figuring out the orientation of things.

LED/Battery and Final Steps

This is probably the most difficult part, both to do and explain. So first, just look at the picture above for a second (sorry it is a little blurry).

So, on the bottom shell, you'll notice a small bump in the middle. This is where the top of the led should line up. Before gluing or bending anything, look at the pictures and the parts you have to get an idea of where you need to place things and how the legs of the LED need to be bent. Keep in mind that you need to leave some space between the side of the LED and the and battery holder. You'll also need to trim a bit of the wall on the top shell's middle slit to allow the LED legs to pass through. Do this after you've got the LED/Battery holder glued down to make sure you trim in the right spot.
Now, trim the legs of the LED about halfway or so. It’s better to leave them too long and have to trim more later than to take off too much and waste an LED. Keeping them parallel to each other, bend both as shown in the picture (the orange line). Insert one leg into each hole on the top/bottom of the battery holder. You may have to bend the very tips of the legs toward each other a tiny bit to make this easier. Now, holding the LED at roughly the angle it need to be, stuff a battery in. This should finish bending the legs and press them against the roof and floor of the battery holder. If the LED doesn't light, you probably just have it upside down. You can remove the battery by pushing a pen in the small hole on its side.
I left the battery in for this next part as it helped hold the LED tightly in place and gave me a solid piece to put a tiny spring clamp on. Mix up some more green stuff and put a small blob on the bottom of the battery holder. Mash it into the bottom shell, keeping in mind where the walls of the top shell will be and also getting the LED lined up in the correct spot. Before the green stuff sets, figure out where you need to trim the wall in the top shell's slot, and use a flush cutter, small scissors, or x-acto knife to do so. Do a bit of a test fit to make sure your battery placement will work. Use a small weight or clamp to keep everything pressed into place. After the green stuff has hardened, the battery holder may pop off. This is ok, just put some glue on it and stick it back in place.

Next up, you can put in the transparent bar of the top shell. It should press fit without glue, just be careful with placement. The bar may be a tad long, so you might have to sand down the end (the one opposite the curve) to get it to fit flush.

One final step now. The focus probably won’t sit on your head right. The clip will be too loose or tight or the focus will be pointing down or up too far. To fix this, you’ll need to take the ear clip off, gently heat it with a hair dryer or hot air gun and bend it to a better shape. Be careful not to heat the section between the magnets and don’t apply too much heat. Just gentle heat and small adjustments, holding it in shape until it cools. Try it on between each adjustment and make more adjustments as needed.

That’s about it. I know it looks daunting, but it’s not so bad once you get working. One final note on the battery. That thing should last you forever. I’ve been using the same battery to test each of the 5 focuses I’ve built, leaving them overnight each time (so 40+ hours) and it stills seems to light up the LED just as bright. If the battery ever does die, make sure you replace it with the exact same kind of battery. Anything else either won’t fit the holder, won’t be powerful enough to light the LED, or will be too strong and blow it out. Good luck and have fun!

Designed using 123d design.

title: Butterfly Knife Comb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The 'Butterfly Knife Comb' is designed to represent a knife used in the popular CS:GO video game. This was designed at the request of a Thingiverse member. They look great, functions as a comb surprisingly well but aren't that realistic that they could be confused for the real thing (...which could cause issues!).

This is a one piece print. The handles do not move / fold around the blade. This could have been done but, in the interests of ensuring it's not seen as being the real thing, has been kept simple and solid. This also means it is an easy print for anyone with a machine with a large enough build plate (...if your machine is borderline for printing this at full size try putting it on the build plate diagonally and possibly scaling it down a fraction)

This is an easy print that doesn't use much filament. At standard scale the knife is 20cm in length. It should be able to be scaled or down 20 - 30% with no print issues however going too far in either direction may result is functional problems such as the prongs being too thin / weak of too thick to comb well. If you are scaling it, as a suggestion, scale only X and Y (not Z) by the same amounts. This will resize it and retain the shape but leave the prongs the same height.

The (CS:GO) Butterfly Knife Comb is a fun, novelty print for your own use as well as making a great gift for gamers. Print in your / their favourite color. Please post images of your prints for other members to see...

Using a raft is recommended for ease of removal from the build plate as well as ensuring the prongs aren't damaged during the process.

Please refer to the images and print settings / instructions for additional information.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 25% infill or more to make sure the prongs are strong

Notes:

Easy print... using a raft is recommended for ease of removal from the build plate plus also to help ensure the prongs are not damaged in the process.

Using higher than usual infill is recommended (25% or more) to make sure the prongs are strong so it functions as a comb well.
Just remove the raft and comb your hair!

description.text:
Y-Carriage designed for my HICTop Prusa Mendel I3. This carriage fits a 272mm x 220mm heat bed.

I made this carriage because my old one kept rattling, this one does't rattle at all! The real key was a simple little thing:
You know the three bolts with springs on them that connect your heatbed to your carriage? Each of those bolts must be secured to the carriage at two points or they will shake. In the final embodiment of this carriage I ended up flipping the bolts upside down such that I put the level-adjustment wingnuts on top of my heatbed. So, each bolt is clamped to the carriage with two regular nuts and then the spring tension is adjusted with the wingnuts on top, the bolts never move! (See image)

https://youtu.be/z2-a6z1lBK0
